contentrichtext.text: [[File:Boxing ring.jpg|thumb|right|An [[International Boxing Association|AIBA]] full-sized competition ring. Dimensions are 23 ft x 23 ft (20 ft x 20 ft inside), with a 3 ft platform height.]] A '''boxing ring''' is the space in which a [[boxing]] match occurs. A modern ring, which is set on a raised platform, is square with a post at each corner to which four parallel rows of ropes are attached with a [[turnbuckle]]. Unlike its cousin the [[wrestling ring]], the ropes in a boxing ring are generally secured at the midway point. ==Construction== As there are a number of [[:Category:Professional boxing organisations|professional boxing organizations]], the standards of construction vary. A standard ring is between {{convert|16|and|25|ft|m}} to a side between the ropes with another {{convert|2|ft|m}} outside. The platform the ring is on is generally {{convert|3|to|4|ft|m}} from the ground with the posts rising around {{convert|5|ft|m}}. The ring itself has around {{convert|1|in|mm}} of padding covered by stretched [[canvas]]. The ropes are around {{convert|1|in|mm}} in diameter and held up on posts rising around {{convert|5|ft|m}} at heights of 18, 30, 42, and 55 inches (.46, .76, 1.07, and 1.37 m). ==Terminology== The name ring is a relic from when contests were fought in a roughly drawn circle on the ground. The name ring continued with the [[Jack Broughton]] [[London Prize Ring rules|rules]] in 1743, which specified a small circle in the centre of the fight area where the boxers met at the start of each round. The first square ring was introduced by the [[Pugilistic Society]] in 1838. That ring was specified as {{convert|24|ft|m}} square and bound by two ropes. For these and other reasons, the boxing ring is commonly referred to as the "square circle". ==See also== * [[Ring girl]] * [[Wrestling ring]] {{boxing}} [[Category:Boxing|*]]
